course.subject: HUMA
course.name: Enjoyment of Western Opera
course.description: An examination of the historical development of western opera, and selected western operas with their related literary texts. This course will also put some emphasis on works that are related to Asian cultures, and operas that will be performed in Hong Kong. No previous knowledge of opera is required.

reviews.author: Doug Stamper
reviews.title: Opera
reviews.comment_content:
The course covers 4 periods, ordered ascendingly,
0. Before Baroque
1. Baroque period
2. Classical period
3. Romantic period
4. 20th century.
However, the order is different,
1. Classical period
2. Baroque period
3. Romantic period
4. 20 century.
The professor covered prominent operas or operas that embody certain period, for example
1. Classical period
Barber Seville (Opera buffa)
Don Giovanni (Drama giocoso)
2. Baroque period
The enchanted period (Composed not at the Baroque period but it sounds like it)
3. Before Baroque period
L'Orfeo (seconda pratica)
4. Romantic period
Carmen
Ring Cycle
5. 20th century
Nixon to China
Wozeck

You should expect many terms of opera being covered, for example
1. singer types (tenor, counter tenor)
2. singing styles (aria, recitative)
3. opera types (opera buffa, opera seria)
4. music theory (diatonic)
reviews.comment_teaching:
In my opinion, his pacing is so slow. He talks too slow. Since it was online teaching, there were times when I literally slept during the lecture.
He is a passionate teacher and baritone, which is an archetype of opera singers. So you can expect many singings and keyboard demonstrations throughout the lectures.
He is kind, for example, he is willing to delay the deadline of quizzes.

People are not doing so hot in mid-term listening.
Tho they are quite good at MC and short answer.
The professor is kinda strict in the project.
The following are my grades, not bad to be quite frank.
Discussion 1,2,3,5:2/2
Discussion 4:0/2
Quiz 1: 20/20
quiz 2: 18/20

Quiz 5: 19/20

reviews.comment_workload:
Yes, on paper, this course has insurmountable workload. But, off the record, it just isn't the case.
1. Operas
Don't watch them before the lecture. Without context, it makes no difference between watching and not. Besides, the professor will play the entire thing during lecture. Besides, the exam will only cover A FEW segments from A FEW operas.
2. Quizzes
5 Canvas quizzes within 20 minutes. Sounds like a speedrun eh?
Nein.
Ask yourself some questions:
How many power points are covered in this quiz?
Have I memorized the title of each power point slide?
Have I read the synopsis of the covered opera?
How long do I need to take care of all the above?
That's it.
3. Discussion board
Do it a few hours before the deadline when almost everyone has made their comments.
Make sure you have bare minimal knowledge.
Paraphrase.
End of story.
4. Mid-term
There are 3 parts:
MC, short question, listening
Make sure you ask yourself the following questions:
1. Did i memorize the title of each power point slide?
2. Do I vaguely understand the context of each power point slide?
3. Did I memorize all the synopsis of all covered operas?
4. How long do I need to take care of the above?
5. Are you readied to google when you completely forget which power point should you refer to?
That's it for MC and short question.
For listening,
Just replace your songlist with all those opera segments 5 days before the exam.
Loop until you can vaguely recognize the pattern.
Then make sure you memorize the
- Composer
- Period
- Context
You are through.
6. Project
You need good teammates, which I had. Not sure about you though.
7. Final
Same as mid-term. Except there is essay.
But my method is just to conclude each power point chronologically.
And I got full credits out of it. LMAO
8. Attendance
I can't focus during the lecture as I mentioned before, it is boring. I just attended it. Then got the recording and watch it at 2x speed to get the context. Knowing the context will be more than sufficient since there are a lot of fat in lectures that were trimmed in ALL assessments.

As you can see, you don't even need to be passionate to get good grades. It had also come to my attention that it is kind of useless to really study all stuff in depth if you are not that into music or opera. The professor will play the parts which he thinks important and go into details that will not even appear in any assessments.

reviews.author: Ahmed Mahomed
reviews.comment_content: Covers many fundamental operas across various periods. Begins with early Italian periods such as Classical, Late Classical, or Baroque, and then moves to cover French, Spanish, German and even English opera as they emerge historically.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Droscha aims to make class enjoyable for students even if they don't enjoy the subject matter. He plays the piano and sings to show examples and plays clips from operas to emphasize points. Very nice guy.
reviews.comment_grading: Rather lenient professor. He is willing to listen to your emails and grades all the exams in a fair format. If you study even a little, you'll receive at least a B in this course.
reviews.comment_workload:
The main course load is 5 quizzes, which are taken online and can be done at any time throughout the week. All of the quiz questions come directly from the powerpoints and are usually simple vocab terms.

There is also an essay in the form of an Opera Review. This can be done any time in the semester after watching an opera in person, rather easy to do.

reviews.comment_workload:
Insane workload, would not recommend it!!!!
The weekly quizzes were very time-consuming, despite it being open book, we had a 20-minute time frame to finish 20 mc questions on canvas. Moreover, professor Isaac did not show the operas in class, we had to watch them in our own spare time before class. He would then explain what concepts were used in the opera in class, so if you didn't watch the opera, you wouldn't be able to follow along at all. The midterm and final exam consisted of knowing concepts in opera, the main plots of the operas, and memorizing the songs that were played in the opera (he gave us a list of the songs he will quiz such as the title, composer and from which opera it was from.) He would play it during the exam and you had to identify which composer wrote it, from which opera it was from and what was happening in the scene when the song was being played. There is also a group project (our group had 10 ppl in it) We had to choose to modernize a opera of our choice and plan the whole thing from start to finish. We had to rewrite the plot, draw costumes, design background sets, and also choose the venue for our opera and include the financial side of it such as the price of the tickets, venue, expected sales and profit, etc. The opera review required us to attend 2 concerts and 1 workshop and then write a detailed review of them at the end of the term. This course had a lot of workload for a common core course.

reviews.comment_workload:
Heavy workload !!!
Feel like a four-credit major course.
It contains all forms of tasks, it have midterm exam, final exam, group project, presentation, essay, discussions, quizzes and attendance. It takes a lot of time throughout the sem.

The exam questions are also very diverse, including MC, listening, fill-in-the-blank, and essays. The final exam was three hours long, and I was really tired. And the listening questions are based on listening to clips to let you determine which opera, who wrote it, and what the plot is about. So you must be familiar with all the songs in the playlist.

Overall, the tasks examined are numerous and come in various forms.

reviews.author: Kellz
reviews.comment_content:
The content covers the history of opera, features and techniques discovered in different opera. As a musically inclined person myself, it was an easy course for me because I was already quite familiar with classical music history and characteristics. However, some of my friends who are not familiar with music still found it a fun course and found the content manageable.

In the midterm, we were required to know the features and technical terms covered in class, as well as listen to snippets of the operas and be able to recognise them and explain briefly their plots. The final exam included some short answer questions and one long essay.

The weekly discussion forums and quizzes were a bit of a pain but still doable.
reviews.comment_teaching: Isaac was really good at explaining the musical concepts clearly in a lively manner. I seldom got bored because he always incorporated humour in his teaching. He's also a very easygoing professor, e.g. when some of us accidentally missed one week of discussion forum, he would open it up again for us to complete it.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is decent. I got above mean for both exams and got an A in the end. As long as you attend class, complete the discussions and quizzes and opera review essay, study for the exams, do a decent job at the group project and presentation, you'll get a decent grade.
reviews.comment_workload: As mentioned previously, there are quite a bit of work in the course with many kinds of assessment tasks, but all of them are manageable if you enjoy getting to know and appreciating opera.

reviews.author: driftwood
reviews.title: An absolute must even for those who hate opera
reviews.comment_content: You get to watch a bunch of operas throughout the sem, some better, some worse, but overall it's kind of like watching a movie and is quite entertaining. Mostly definitions/theory, but it's really simple.
reviews.comment_teaching: Isaac is a KING. It is clear from his style and passion that he truly loves the subject. He is an opera singer himself. Professor Droscha is really funny and down to earth, very engaging, and it's always a pleasure to go to his class. Everything about him is lovely. He is very helpful and always happy to chat after class and help you with anything.
reviews.comment_grading: Not very harsh, as long as you get 20/20 on most quizzes you're set.
reviews.comment_workload: Not too much apart from watching the operas which can be time consuming. There is some pre-class reading but he doesn't really check if you've done it and it does not come up on quizzes. The most annoying part is perhaps that along with a final exam you have to make a group presentation AND write a 1500-word opera review.

reviews.author: JunePumpkin
reviews.title: Super easy cc
reviews.comment_content:
You will learn about the background of composers and the traits of operas of different period, start from 1500s to 20 centuries. It might sound a lot to learn, but it is not.

As long as you focus in class, and do some revision every week, you will be fine. Professor said this course was "non-cumulative", but that's not the case, as some of the content before the midterm will appear again in the final.

Don't worry if you don't have any music background, it doesn't matter at all. I don't have any music background as well, but I still got an A. The music concepts are easy to understand, and strict forward. You just have to memorize the "definition" of the musical terms, and that's more than enough.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very friendly professor, nice class interaction
He is willing to postpone the deadlines, so we could have more time to revise, work on our essay and group project.
reviews.comment_grading:
Online quizzes are quite easy, all in MC format, most student could get 19 or 20 out of 20, as long as you revised. Most answers could be directly found on notes, except one or two, so if you target to get full marks in every quizzes, you might need to pay extra attention in classes.

Midterm and final are quite similar, both contain MC, short questions and listening questions. You have to listen to a short audio clip and distinguish which opera is it from. Final exam has one more extra part, you have to write a 1000-word essay, but no need to worry too much, as the essay topics would be provided a few days earlier, so you can actually prepare for the essay beforehand.

The group project is very easy and chill, there will be around 8-9 people in one group, most of us can get quite a good grade.

Overall, I think it is very easy to get A range for this course, as long as you revised.

reviews.comment_content:
Introduction
Listening to Opera
Il Barbiere di Siviglia/Voice types/Role types
Opera of the Classical period and Don Giovanni
Baroque opera and The Enchanted Island
The invention and beginnings of opera and La favola d'Orfeo
Rigoletto and the bel canto style
Verdi Vs. Wagner and the music drama & The Business of Opera
Wagner and the development of the motive
Carmen
Puccini and La Boheme
The 20th Century

Before midterm Introduce opera from classical to baroque era then continued from baroque to romantic and 20th century. Kind of jumping forward and backward. Really learn something about opera after this class.
I would say if you don't like opera, just don't enroll
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching was clear and nice. But as a full online mode this semester, he seems to be like the strictest attendance police keep asking students to turn on the video. No accent, fluent English teaching.
reviews.comment_grading:
Attendance-10%
(attendance including attending the lectures and answering questions in class)
5 Online Quizzes-10%
(quizzes are quite easy, just ppt stuff and may be done by yourself after class)
6 Discussion posts-10%
(posting opinions on canvas with at least 150 words and a reply with 30 words )
Midterm-20%
(Most MC and fill in blanks in listening questions)
Opera Review-10%
(at least 1000 words )
Group Project (need presentation)-15%
(make an opera production including costumes and sets designs and budgets)
Final Exam- 25%
(MC, fill in the blanks, listening, and short answer questions and essay with 800 words in four sections with time limits)

It seemed like absolute grading, got nearly 93 percent overall and turned out A-
reviews.comment_workload: Though most students think the workload is light, I would say I was fooled by the reviews. Need to watch opera nearly every week. Reading materials were optional. There were quizzes discussion, posts, and exams nearly every week. With a group project (10 people) and presentation. Besides, a review based on the assigned opera with more than 1000 words. At last, there was a final with 3 hours length including MC, fill in the blanks, listening, and short answer questions and essay with 800 words. To be honest, as a tough semester, the final really made me struggle.  BTW, listening questions appeared in midterm and final, you have to be familiar with those songs in operas, by listening to the recording in the questions you have to figure out which opera does it comes from, the composers and the plot.
